content.webTitle: Bonus points to become permanent fixture at Six Nations

fields.headline: Bonus points to become permanent fixture at Six Nations
fields.bodyText: Bonus points have been made a permanent fixture of the Six Nations and the tournament’s chief executive, John Feehan, has suggested they could prove pivotal in deciding the winners of this year’s championship. Last year bonus points were adopted on a trial basis for the first time in the competition’s 125-year history. During last year’s tournament 11 bonus points were awarded but they did not have a direct impact on the final standings with England having already sealed the successful defence of their title before a final weekend defeat by Ireland. “Overall we’re very happy with bonus points,” said Feehan, “It’s very hard to give you empirical evidence that it’s better. But we believe overall, on balance, that it was a good decision and we’re going to keep it. It certainly didn’t take away from anything. It’s a very evenly matched tournament this year and we think the bonus points may have more of an impact this time.” Feehan also confirmed the tournament will remain the same length with two fallow weekends after England, who wanted the competition truncated, were outvoted five-one at a Six Nations board meeting in September. “You can’t bring it down below seven weeks because the guys can’t perform at that level five weeks on the trot,” he said. “It’s particularly unfair on the smaller nations – England and France might have the resources to do that but others don’t. The reality is we need to keep the integrity of the tournament right and so we need to have the rest weeks to do that.” Feehan said the Six Nations would be happy to move the traditional start date at the beginning of February back by two weeks as part of the new restructured global calendar, due to come in to force after the 2019 World Cup. That could mean the tournament finishing in early April and therefore cause a potential clash with the Champions Cup quarter-finals. “If the start date is pushed back to start in the middle of February, that’s OK, it’s no big deal there,” he said.
